explanation:
OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET — macro (or accessor) used to obtain impl; its expansion may contain control structures (including for loops) or side-effects, so the expansion must be inspected to be sure no for-loop violations are introduced.

OS_ObjectIndexFromToken — appears in the static call graph and is commonly used by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; its implementation must be checked because any for-loops inside it (or side-effects on loop counters/flags) count toward MISRA’s for-loop rule when called from this function/macro.

OS_impl_condvar_table — the table/object passed to OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; its type/layout and any accessors may influence the macro expansion or introduce loops/side-effects.

OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t — the type of *impl; needed to confirm the members accessed (cv, mut) and their types (pthread_cond_t / pthread_mutex_t) and to ensure no hidden macros/wrappers produce for-loops when accessing members.

OS_object_token_t — the token type that is dereferenced (*token) in the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET call; its definition could affect macro behavior or generate expressions that include loops or side-effects.

OS_SUCCESS, OS_ERROR — symbolic constants assigned to final_status; include them to confirm they are simple macros/enum values with no side-effects (so they don’t violate the ‘‘no persistent side effects’’ clause if ever used in loop clauses).

pthread_cond_destroy, pthread_mutex_destroy — functions called by this function; while there is no for-loop in the target, MISRA requires examining functions called inside loop bodies. Also verify these functions are ordinary library calls (no macros expanding to for-loops or modifications of loop counters) and that their use here does not implicate loop-related rules.

pthread_cond_t, pthread_mutex_t — the types of impl->cv and impl->mut; included to check whether member access uses any wrappers/macros that could contain loops or side-effects.

Rationale summary: the MISRA rule concerns the well-formedness of for-loops and includes the behaviour of any functions/macros called within the loop. Although OS_CondVarDelete_Impl itself contains no for loop, the macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and the called helper OS_ObjectIndexFromToken (and any macros/types involved in member access) must be inspected to ensure they do not introduce for-loops or side-effects that would trigger a MISRA violation. The symbols above are the minimal set required to perform that inspection.
